children.name: Computer Systems & General Knowledge
General Knowledge
Common Knowledge
Recognise different types of technology and their uses.
Explain the concept of a epoch, a particular period of time in history or a person's life.
Explain the concept of turning at an angle from your current orientation.
Be able to find common angles from the view of two conjoining lines.
Explain the features that make up a circle (centre, radius, diameter).
Explain that an input or interface is a way to interact with a computer.
Computer Knowledge
Explain that computer time is measure in total seconds from the last epoch (1st January 1970).
Explain that typing and reading are measure in WPM (Word Per Minute).
Explain an average and productive typing speed.
Explain the concept of data.
Explain the difference between human and computer time.
Hardware and Software
Hardware
Explain that hardware is the physical portion of a computer.
Recognise different types of hardware.
Identify different pieces of hardware in Computer Systems.
Explain a motherboard and its role to connect all other ascpects of a system.
Explain a power supply  and its role to supply a system with adequate power.
Explain a CPU (Central Processing Unit) and its role to process commands.
Explain that a CPU fetches instruction from the memory.
Explain examples of CPU instructions.
Explain a GPU (Graphical Processing Unit) and its role to process visual elements to a display.
Explain memory and its role to retain information.
Explain an SSD (Solid State Drive) and its role to store data.
Explain an SSD is non-volatile.
Explain that an SSD is a non mechanical storage method.
Explain a HDD (Hard Disk Drive) and its role to store data.
Explain an HDD is non-volatile.
Explain that an HDD is a mechanical storage method.
Compare and contrast a SSD and HDD as forms of storage.
Explain RAM (Random Access Memory) and its role as a temporary but fast data store.
Explain that RAM (Random Access Memory) is volatile.
Compare and contrast volatile and non- volatile memory.
Software
Explain different uses of software.
Describe the use of software in a computer system.
Relationship between Hardware and Software
Compare the difference between software and hardware in computer systems.
Computer Systems
Hardware
Discuss the purpose of hardware devices such as CPU
Describe and explain the various characteristics of a CPU
Expain how characteristsics effect the performance of the CPU.
Explain the purpose and characteristics of embedded systems
Identify examples of embedded systems
Software classification
To understand the purpose of an operating system.
To understand that an operating system provides processor management.
To understand that an operating system provides memory management.
To understand that an operating system provides device management.
To understand that an operating system provides application management.
To understand that an operating system provides security management.
Explain the need for, and functions of utility programs.
Compare utility and application software.
Describe the purpose of application software.
Explain what is meant by system software and application software, giving examples of both types of software.
Systems architecture
Expain the characteristics and roles of RAM
Expain the characteristics and roles of ROM
Expain the characteristics and roles of Cache Register
Expain the characteristics and roles of Virtual Memory.
Explain what the different types of memory are used for and why they are required.
Explain the term main memory
Explain the term secondary storage
Compare main memory and secondary storage.
Compare RAM (volatile memory) and ROM (non-volatile memory).
Explain why secondary storage is required.
Explain the Von Neumann architecture in separating the program from the machine.
Describe an ‘Instruction Set’
Explain the CPU Fetch process
Explain the CPU Decode process
Explain the CPU Execute process
Illustrate the Fetch-Decode-Execute cycle
Explain roles of specialised CPU registers during the Fetch-Decode-Execute cycle.
Explain the term 'cloud storage'
Describe 'cloud computing'.
Define secondary storage.
Describe Solid State Storage
Describe Optical Storage
Describe Magnetic Storage
Explain the operation of solid state, optical and magnetic storage.
Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of solid state, optical and magnetic storage.
Explain the term 'NAS - Network Attached Storage'.
Explain the advantages and disadvantages of cloud storage when compared to local storage.
Define the term main memory
Define RAM
Define ROM
Define CACHE Memory
Explain the purpose of CACHE memory
Define primary storage
Define Virtual Memory
Explain what capacitors are used for
Explain what transistors are used for.
Compare and contrast capacitors and transistors
Define the Von Neumann architecture
Explain the role and operation of a central processing unit (CPU) within the Von Neumann architecture
Explain the effect of the following on the performance of the CPU: clock speed
Explain the effect of the following on the performance of the CPU: number of processor
Explain the effect of the following on the performance of the CPU: cores
Explain the effect of the following on the performance of the CPU: cache type
Explain the effect of the following on the performance of the CPU: cache size
Explain the role of a CPU’s instruction set.
Explain the CISC CPU instruction set
Explain the RISC CPU instruction set.
Compare and contrast the CISC and RISC CPU’s instruction sets.
Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each type of processor (RISC and CISC).
Boolean logic
Construct truth tables for the following logic gates NOT
Construct truth tables for the following logic gates AND
Construct truth tables for the following logic gates OR
Construct truth tables for the following logic gates XOR
Construct truth tables for simple logic circuits.
Interpret the results of simple truth tables.
Create, modify and interpret simple logic circuit diagrams.
Create and interpret simple Boolean expressions made up of NOT, AND, OR and XOR operations.
Create the Boolean expression for a simple logic circuit.
Create a logic circuit from a simple Boolean expression.
Be able to indentify the 'AND' logic gate and its operation
Be able to indentify the 'OR' logic gate and its operation
Be able to indentify the 'NOT' logic gate and its operation
GUI (Graphic User Interface)
GUI Basics
Explain the term GUI (Graphical User Interface)
Explain common interactions we use everyday with a GUI
Explain UX (User eXperience) finding the best usability for your application
Be able to map out a user experience to a flowchart of events
Be able to map out commonly used portions  of an application, such as a grid of buttons with similar events
Fundamentals of computer networks
Fundamentals of computer networks
Define the term ‘network protocol’.
Explain the link layer.
Explain the internet layer
Explain the transport layer
Explain the application layer
Describe the 4 layer TCP/IP model: application layer transport layer internet layer link layer.
Decribe HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol)
Decribe HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure)
Describe SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol)
Describe IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol)
Describe FTP (File Transfer Protocol)
Describe IP (Internet Protocol)
Describe TCP (Transmission Control Protocol)
Describe UDP (User Datagram Protocol)
Describe how the HTTP, HTTPS, SMTP, IMAP and FTP protocols operate at the application layer.
Describe how the TCP and UDP protocols operate at the transport layer.
Understand that the IP protocol operates at the internet layer.
Explain IP Addressing
Explain MAC Addressing
Explain a wired network
Explain a wireless network
Explain why networks can be wired or wireless.
Discuss the benefits and risks of wireless networks as opposed to wired networks.
Explain the purpose and use of common network protocols for ethernet
Explain the purpose and use of common network protocols for Wi-Fi
Explain how different data transfer mediums carry data.
Explain how data is transmitted across a network.
Explain what is meant by the term ‘protocol’.
Define what a computer network is.
Describe a Local Area Network (LAN)
Explain the benefits and drawbacks of a LAN.
Identify the devices required to form a network.
Describe a Wide Area Network (WAN)
Explain the benefits and drawbacks of a WAN
Explain the purpose of an Internet Service Provider (ISP)
Describe an IP  Address
Discuss the benefits and risks of computer networks.
Explain the following common network topology: STAR.
Explain the following common network topology: BUS.
Explain the following common network topology: MESH*.
Programming Fundamentals
Variables
Variables Basic Concepts
To understand how computers store information using Variables.
Recognise the abstract idea of Memory Boxes (variables) to real-life situations.
Explain Variables have a Name and a Value.
Apply a Variable with a Name and a Value.
Explain Variables can only hold one Value at one time.
Use assignment operator to assign a value to a variable, for instance variable = expression.
Explain that a Variable Value can be updated using another Variable.
Update a Variable value by another Variable using "=".
Identify a valid variable name.
Use of Variables
Apply the use of Variables in Conditionals
Apply the use of Variables in Loops
Apply the concept of Variables in algebra
Local Variables
Explain that subroutines may declare their own variables, called local variables.
Recall that local variables only exist while the subroutine is executing
Explain why local variables are only accessible within the subroutine
Use local variables and explain why it is good practice to do so.
Global Variables
Explain that global variables can be visited by all the subroutines in the program
Explain if one subroutine changes a global variable, the new value will be seen by all the subroutines.
Demonstrate the difference between local variables and global variables.
Constants
Explain that constants are the data that is unlikely to change.
Explain that constants are the opposites of variables.
Demonstrate the advantages of using named constants.
Variables Data Types
Describe the definition of datatypes
Demonstrate a String (or str or text) is one of four datatypes that is used for a combination of any characters that appear on a keyboard, such as letters, numbers and symbols.
Demonstrate how to count characters in a string
Demonstrate that an Integer (or Int) is one of four datatypes that is used for whole numbers
Demonstrate that a Float (or Real) is one of four datatypes that is used for numbers that contain decimal points, or for fractions.
Demonstrate a Boolean (or Bool) is one of four datatypes where data is restricted to True/False or Yes/No options.
Variable Casting
Explain the concept of variable casting by converting a variable to different datatype
Demonstrate convertion from a float or a String to an Integer
Demonstrate convertion from an integer or a String to a Float
Demonstrate convertion from a float or an integer to a String
Operators
Arithmetic Operators
Demonstrate how arithmetic operators use one element on another
Identify addition as one of the arithmetic operators
Identify subtraction as one of the arithmetic operators
Identify multiplication as one of the arithmetic operators
Identify real division as one of the arithmetic operators
Identify integer division as one of the arithmetic operators
Operate using addition
Operate using subtraction
Operate using multiplication
Operate using real division
Operate using integer division
Explain a modulus operation
Determine the value of a variable through operations
Comparison Operators
Demonstrate how comparison operators use one element on another
Recognise the "equal to" operator
Recognise the "not equal to" operator
Recognise the "less than" operator
Recognise the "greater than" operator
Recognise the "less than or equal to" operator
Recognise the "greater than or equal to" operator
Use "equal to" operator
Use "not equal to" operator
Use "less than" operator
Use "greater than" operator
Use "less than or equal to" operator
Use "greater than or equal to" operator
Boolean
Boolean Values
Recoganise Boolean Values as True and False
Apply Boolean Values to individual events
Use Boolean Values in a Statement
Use Boolean Values in Maths
Boolean Operations
Recognise the Boolean operator "NOT"
Recognise the Boolean operator "AND"
Recognise the Boolean operator "OR"
Recognise the Boolean operator "XOR"
Use the Boolean operator "NOT"
Use the Boolean operator "AND"
Use the Boolean operator "OR"
Use the Boolean operator "XOR"
Create an algorithm by using the Boolean operators "And", "Not" and "Or"
Describe a Boolean expression
Boolean Expressions
Use Boolean expressions in IF Statements
Use Boolean expressions in Loops
Conditionals
Simple Conditionals
Explain what a conditional decision is in a Flow Chart
IF statements
Demonstrate Boolean values True or False in IF Statement
Demonstrate IF statement connecting multiple events
Demonstrate a selection statement incuding an ELSE Statement
Demonstrate nested selection statements
Demonstrate how ELIF can be used to check another condition
Loops
Loop Basics
Demonstrate Loops are repetitions of events
Demonstrate the sequences of looping events
Demonstrate optimisation of loops
Count controlled loops (FOR)
Explain that a "FOR" Loop is count controlled, with a predetermined stop point
Discuss how a "FOR" Loop holds the current index as a variable
Discuss how a "FOR" Loop uses the break command to leave early
Explain that a "FOR" Loop uses an "ELSE" statement make a section of code run when once the loop is successful
Be able to explain the purpose of a given "FOR" Loop in code
Create FOR loops to solve simple real-life problems
Event controlled loops (While)
Explain that While loops are event controlled, the event controls when it stops. Not always pretermined.
Illustrate how While loops can use comparators to determine the stop point
Functions
Function Basics
Demonstrate functions as a machine, with inputs and outputs
Demonstrate functions as lists of code, sequence of events
Illustrate how functions have repeatability and can be called into action
Create an algorithm showing Function formatting (repeat, nesting)
Create an algorithm showing Function formatting (define, indent)
Function Concepts
Discuss how Functions can have inputs, and how they are used within the code structure
Discuss how Functions can return elements to the point of Function call
Demonstrate nested elements within a Function (if)
Demonstrate nested elements within a Function (for)
Demonstrate nested elements within a Function (while)
Function uses and relations
Be able to use the print function in a solution
Be able to use the range function in a solution
Be able to use the int function in a solution
Be able to use the input function in a solution
Be able to use the remove function in a solution
Describe how Min finds minumum, Max finds maximum
Explain how an eval() function performs maths operations on an expression
Use the eval() function to perform math operations on an expression
Explain that a lambda function is a small anonymous function.
Use the lambda() function
Recognise the different components of a Python function i.e. def, name and code
Be able to return values from a function
Differentiate between inputs, parameters and arguments
Create default values accurately
Recognise and use common built-in functions i.e. print, input, range, len
Differentiate between inner and outer functions of nested functions
Understand variable accessibility from within nested functions
Strings
String basics
Demonstrate how Strings hold characters, symbols, word or sentences
Be able to use indices to locate individual characters in a string
Be able to identify the validity of a string
String operations
Illustrate the division of strings to substrings
Use string related functions, append, extend, remove, sort etc
Be able to permutate a string to find an anagram of a string
String Operations
Be able to use a carriage return '/r' to move the cursor to the beginning of the same line
Be able to use a new line operator '/n' to move the cursor down one line
Be able to use a string placeholder '%s' to insert string data into a string
Be able to use a numeric placeholder '%d' to insert numeric data into a string
Be able to differentiate the different outputs when using arithmetic operators on Strings and Integers and a combination of both
Be able to take in user input and cast the inputs from String to either int or float
Demonstrate in-built functions that modify the case of a String i.e. upper(), lower(), title(), capitalize()
Demonstrate in-built functions that alter Strings or output findings i.e. split(), strip(), count(), replace()
Modules/Libraries
Module Basics
Discuss why Modules/libraries are collections of useful functions
Use Modules/libraries and related functions to improve programs
Choose and import Modules/libraries that are fit for purpose when creating an algorithm
Combine Modules/libraries functions when creating algorithms.
Explain the different methods of 'importing' libraries and using the correct syntax to call their functions
Turtle Module/Library
Import and use cases of the turtle library in an algorithm
Use Turtle related functions (draw, lift, drop, circle, colour)
Combine computational ideas and Turtle functions
Use the turtle library to draw common shapes
PyGame Module/Library
Import and use cases of the PyGame library
Use PyGame related functions and building (loading, attaching)
Use PyGame related functions and building (removing, sprites)
PyGame related game creation principles
PyGame  Module/Library
Use a interface (such as a mouse or keyboard) to define/change the position of an element
Implement a 'clock' or framerate (FPS)
Math Module/Library
Import and use cases for the math library
Use math related functions and expressions (ceil, floor)
Use the math library to assist in refining or filtering your data
Use the math library in conjuction with other functions (casting, nesting, expressions)
Time  Module/Library
Use cases for the Time library
Use time related functions and expressions (time, strptime, ctime)
Use the time library in conjuction with other functions, fetching the time for different applications
Use the time library as a method to present time taken for a result
Use the time library to convert time into different formats or time zones
Turtle  Module/Library
Explain that the turtle moves based a set number of inputted pixels
Explain the comparison between a 'turtle' and a pen
tkinter Module/Library
Import and use cases for the tkinter library
Use tkinter related functions and building (grid, label, button, screen)
Create simple buttons and events within tkinter
Position items using a coordinate and grid system within a window
Create and manipulate text within a tkinter window
Random Module/Library
Import and use cases for the Random library
Use Random related functions and building (randint, randrange)
Explain why it is inherently difficult to create randomness on a computer
MatplotLib Module/Library
Import and use cases for the MatPlotLib library
Use MatPlotLib related functions and building (bar, pie, line, title, label, show)
Combine database/table structures with MatPlotLob to display data in relevant formats
Recursion
Recursion Basics
Explain that recursion is breaking down a bigger problem into smaller self-calling pieces
Demonstrate a self-concluding recursive action
Apply recursion to solve problems
Logical inference
Implication relation
Discuss the implication relation - if A happens,  then B will happen
Complete the inverse and converse of the implication relation - if B did not happen,  then A did not happen
Apply the implication relation several times to infer a result
Inference using a table
Use a 'database' table to record the facts
Determine the contradictory parts in the logic within a table of data
Determine the unknown facts within a table of data
Inference using a graph
Use a graph to record the facts
Determine the contradictory parts in the logic from a graph
Determine the unknown facts from a graph
Exceptions
Exception Basics
Explain an Exception within a program
Explain what problems can cause exception within a program
Be able to catch an exception when it occurs
Be able to handle an exception when it occurs
Be able to use the 'try' and 'except' keywords
Explain the use of an 'Else' statement following an exception statement
Explain the use of a 'Finally' statement following an exception statement
Programming
Programming Concepts
Explain the purpose of a function in programming
Describe the use of parameters to pass data within programs.
Use subroutines that require more than one parameter.
Describe how data is passed to a subroutine using parameters
Explain the difference between functions and procedures.
Create and breakdown a function or procedure in programming.
Explain the purpose of a definite (count-controlled) loop (FOR).
Use a definite loop with count-controlled conditions.
Use the range function when combined with a loop.
Use and create nested iteration structures with definite loops
Explain the purpose of a indefinite (condition-controlled) loop (WHILE).
Use a indefinite loop with condition-controlled conditions.
Use of the operators when combined with an indefinite and definite loop
Use of the Strings when combined with an indefinite loop
Create a subroutine (procedure/function).
To explain a procedure.
Describe the difference between functions and procedures.
Have the ability to create and breakdown a procedure.
Demonstrate and explain how the following statement types can be combined in programs: sequence, iteration,and selection
Describe the program construct selection
Use and create alogrithms using selection
Identify common programming concept within a block of code
Identify the correct structural flow of a program
Be able to a idenitify recurring pattern
Explain the concept of a nested element
Subrountines (procedures and functions)
Explain the purpose of modules.
Describe when a module should be created.
Reproduce the importing and use of a module
Describe the concept of subroutines.
Explain the advantages of using subroutines in programs.
Describe the use of parameters to pass data within programs.
Use subroutines that return values to the calling routine.
Arithmetic operations in a programming language
Illustrate modulus division and quotient division.

children.cs_category_3_lesson: Arithmetic operations in a programming language

children.name: Be able to identify relational operators
children.cs_category_3_lesson: Relational operations in a programming language

children.name: Data Types
Create and interpret string operations in algorithms, using strings appropriately
Use strings  appropriately within their own programs
Understand boolean and use it appropriately
Classification of programming languages
Explain the concept of machine code
Explain the concept of assembly language
Explain why machine code and assembly language are considered to be low-level languages
Explain the differences between machine code and assembly language .
Explain why all programming code written in high-level or assembly languages must be translated into machine code.
Identify the three common types of program translator [interpreter compiler assembler].
Identify the main differences between these three types of translator [interpreter compiler assembler].
Explain when it would be appropriate to use each type of translator [interpreter compiler assembler].
Describe how source code has to be translated into machine code in order for the CPU to be able to process the program.
Explain a High level computer language
Explain a low level computer language
Compare and contrast High level language with low level langauge
Compare how an interpreter and a compiler translate source code.
Explain the importance of assembly language
Explain the role of an assembler.
Explain the role of an compiler.
Explain the role of an interpreter.
Robust and secure programming
Explain and be able to identify a syntax error
Explain and be able to identify a logic error
Contrast and compare different errors syntax error logic error.
Be able to identify and categorise errors within algorithms and programs.
Write simple data validation routines.
Write simple authentication routines.
Explain the term: Input Validation
Explain the term: Input Sanitation
Explain the term: Authentication
Explain the term: Maintainability
Describe the various strategies that programmers use to ensure that their programs are robust
Use Input Validation for user inputs
Use Input Input Sanitation for user inputs
Explain why errors or exceptions occur
Illustrate handling an exception when thrown
Input/Output and file handling
Create an algorithm to read from/to a text file.
Create an algorithm to write from/to a text file.
Demonstrate the role of the cursor
Create a program to demonstrate the role of the file handler
Data Structures
Use arrays (or equivalent) in the design of solutions to simple problems.
Describe how data is stored in a one dimensional array
Describe how data is stored in a two dimensional array
Perfom operations on a one dimensional array
Perfom operations on a two dimensional array
Data Representation
Data Handling
Data Types
Explain that data stored in variables or other data structures is of different types.
Identify typical data types: strings (texts and symbols), integers (whole numbers), floating point numbers (decimals) and Boolean.
Measuring tools and units
Describe the common measuring tools and units for length
Describe the common measuring tools and units for weight
Describe the common measuring tools and units for volume and capacity
Describe the common measuring tools and units for time
Describe the common measuring tools and units for temperatures, angles and strength of sound
Data collection
Describe the location and methods of data collection
Explain that the raw data are hard to understand
Graphical Data Representation
Interpret, draw and use bar charts
Interpret, draw and use pie charts
Interpret, draw and use line graphs
Define what a chart is
Numerical Data Measures
Explain Min and Max and the use of them in calculations
Execute min and max calculations
Calculate the centre of the data, e.g., mean, median and mode
Perform analysis by applying the centre of the data
File Handling
Load a file from a file path
Close a file once actions are complete
Explain why a file should be closed once actions are complete
Open a file in write or 'w' mode
Explain that writing into a file will overwrite the original content
Open a file in append or 'a' mode
Explain that appending into a file will add new data to the end of the original file
Be able to use the 'with' statement to automatically close a while once complete
Explain how to read a file line by line compared to as whole
Explain that a file is a collection of data
Be able to identify when a program is reading or writing from a file
Ciphers and codes
Cipher Basics
Explain the term cryptography and ciphers as the science of secret messages
Explain the concept and use of a key for encryption and decryption
Explain the term Encryption
Explain the term Decryption
Explain the term plaintext
Create a program to encode a message
Create a program to decode a message
Binary code
Discuss the relationship between on and off, 1 and 0
Demonstrate you can Count in binary
Describe Binary number conversion
Execute Binary number conversion
Execute binary to denary conversion and back.
Complete Denary to Binary Conversation and back.
Complete  binary to hexadecimal conversion and back.
Explain the process of creating a program to convert decimal into denary
Explain the process of creating a program to convert denary into decimal
Morse code
Discuss relations; dits and dahs, dots and dashes
Complete alphabetic conversion to morse code
Encode morse code to letters using the decode tree
Caesar Shifting Ciphers
Demonstrate the dial of Caesar shifting cipher
Encode and decode the Caesar shifting cipher
Vigenère Cipher
Explain the Vigenère Cipher and its use of a keyword for encryption
Encryption and decrypt a Vigenère Cipher using a keyword
Data Representation
Colours
Explain that a colour can be held as a set of Red, Blue and Green codes (RGB)
Explain that RGB has a max value of 255 - 8 Bit Colour
Be able to recite and define common RGB colour codes
Typography
Be able to load and use a Font
Fundamentals of data representation
Number bases
Explain the denary or decimal number system (Base 10)
Explain the binary number system (Base 2)
Explain the hexadecimal number system. (Base 16)
Complete conversions between decimal, hexadecimal and binary
Explain why the hexadecimal number system is used in computer science
Explain why computers use binary to represent all data and instructions
Data compression
Explain what data compression is
Explain why data may be compressed and that there are different ways to compress data.
Describe Lossy Compression
Describe Lossless Compression
Explain how data can be compressed using Huffman coding.
Interpret/create Huffman trees
Calculate the number of bits required to store a piece of data compressed using Huffman coding.
Calculate the number of bits required to store a piece of uncompressed data in ASCII
Explain how data can be compressed using run length encoding (RLE)
Represent data in RLE frequency/data pairs.
Explain how data can be compressed using Dictionary Coding
Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of Dictionary Coding
Explain why we need to encrypt data.
Demonstrate how the Caesar Cypher works.
Compare symmetric and asymmetric encryption.
Units of information
Explain that the bit is the fundamental unit of information
Explain that a byte is a group of 8 bits.
Explain that quantities of bytes can be described using prefixes.
Identify the names, symbols and corresponding values for the  kilo, 1 kB is 1,000 bytes mega
Identify the names, symbols and corresponding values for the mega, 1 MB is 1,000 kilobytes
Identify the names, symbols and corresponding values for the giga, 1 GB is 1,000 Megabytes
Identify the names, symbols and corresponding values for the tera, 1 TB is 1,000 Gigabytes.
Representing images
Describe what a pixel is and be able to describe how pixels relate to an image and the way images are displayed on a computer system.
Explain what is meant by colour depth
Describe that a bitmap can be descirbed by its size in pixels
Describe that a bitmap can be descirbed by its colour depth.
Explain that the size of a bitmap image in pixels (width x height) is known as the image resolution.
Illustrate image resolutsion using the size of a bitmap image in pixels (width x height).
Explain how ‘image resolution’ affects an image’s quality and file size.
Describe how a bitmap represents an image using pixels and colour depth.
Describe using examples how the number of pixels and colour depth can affect the file size of a bitmap image.
Calculate bitmap image file sizes based on the number of pixels and colour depth.
Explain what image meta data is
Representing sound
Describe how sound is analogue and that it must be converted to a digital form for storage and processing in a computer.
Explain that sound waves are sampled to create the digital version of sound.
Describe the digital representation of sound in terms of sampling rate
Describe the digital representation of sound in terms of sample resolution.
Calculate sound file sizes based on the sampling rate and the sample resolution.
Explain what is meant by ‘bit rate’.
Illustrate how ‘bit rate’ affects a sound file’s quality and size.
Calculate the file size of a sound file if its ‘bit rate’ and ‘sample rate’ are known.
Character encoding
Explain what a character set is
Explain the limitations with the ASCII character set.
Describe the 7-bit ASCII character encoding method
Describe the Unicode character encoding method
Explain that character codes are commonly grouped and run in sequence within encoding tables.
Describe the purpose of Unicode
Explain the advantages of Unicode over ASCII.
Identify Unicode uses the same codes as ASCII up to 127.
Identify that all data must eventually be translated into 1 and 0's (Binary)
Data Structures
Graphs
Graphical Data Representation
Explain what a Axis Label is and how it is displayed
Explain what a Axis is and which direction it lays
Explain what a graph Legend is
Be able to decern information for a graph
Graph Basics
Explain that Graphs include nodes and edges
Demonstrate that Graphs can be directed and undirected graphs and edges can have weights
Explain how Graph models are used in real life (e.g., maps, social media relationships, etc)
Graph Traverse
Demonstrate a Breadth first search
Demonstrate a Depth first search
Graph Algorithms - Eulerian paths
Describe the Königsberg Bridge Problem
Discuss in-degrees and out-degrees
Identify when an Eulerian path exists
Find an Eulerian path in a graph
Graph Algorithms - Map Colouring Problems
Discuss the map colouring problem
Model a map using a graph (with nodes and edges)
Illustate that at most 4 colours are needed for any maps
Colour some graphs with at most 4 colours
Graph Algorithms - Tiling Problems
Explain the tiling problem
Discuss why it is impossible to find a solution for some tiling problems
Practise the tiling on some graphs
Graph Algorithms - Shortest Path Problems
Demonstrate the shortest path problem in a graph
Demonstrate how to find the shortest path in a graph
Find a shortest path in some simple graphs
Data Structures
Array Basic Concepts
Explain that an Array has a name and indices
Use the array index to locate an element in an array
Single Dimensional Arrays
Update a value in an array
Swap values in an array
Performing operations on a list - i.e Sorting
Two Dimensional Arrays
Explain the features of a two dimensional array index
Use the array index to locate an element in a two dimensional  array
Create a Two dimensional array index
Describe Swapping values in two dimensional array
Create an algorithm to Swap values in two dimensional array
Coordinate Systems
Describe the feature of a coordinate system
Use coordinates to locate a point in a coordinate system
Use coordinates for a point in a coordinate system
Operations
Be able to append content to the end of a data structure (.append())
Be able to find the length of a data structure (.len())
Be able to find an item within a collection (.index())
Be able to remove an item from a collection (del)
Be able to retrieve an item from a collection using its index
Tuples
Explain that Tuples are used to store multiple items in a single variable.
Be able to create a Tuple
Explain the structure of a Tuple ( ) with the usage of round brackets
Explain that Tuples are collections of ordered information
Explain that Tuples are immutable (unchangeable)
Explain that Tuples allow for duplicate values
Explain that Tuples can have a variety of different datatypes
Explain the differences between a List/Array and a Tuple
Compare and contrast use of Tuples and Lists/Array
Sets
Explain the structure of a set {} with the usage of curly brackets
Explain that sets are collections of unordered information
Explain that tuples are immutable* (unchangeable)
Explain that sets cannot contain duplicate values
Print an entire Set to screen
Add an item to a Set
Remove an item from a Set
Explain that Sets can have a variety of different datatypes
Compare and contrast use of Sets and Lists
Set Operations
Describe a Union operation
Apply a Union operation on two Sets
Describe an Intersection operation
Apply an Intersection operation on two Sets
Describe a Complement operation
Apply a Complement operation on one Set
Sets and Venn Diagrams
Describe Venn diagrams
Draw and interpret Venn diagrams
Explain the Set operations using a Venn diagram
Draw a Venn diagram and work out Set problems in real life
Dictionaries
Explain the structure of a Dictionary {} with the usage of curly brackets and differentiate between key and value pairs
Print an entire Dictionary and a value to screen
Add an item to a Dictionary
Delete an item from a Dictionary
Collections
Compare and contrast Lists, Tuples, Sets and Dictionaries
Queues & Stacks
Queues
Explain the concept of Queues
Demonstrate how Queues follow FIFO (First In First Out) principles
Explain the concept of Queue relations
Demonstate Queue Functions Enqueue and Dequeue
Use a buffer Queue to reoder the items in a Queue
Demonstrate and Explain how to merge two sorted Queues to be one sorted Queue
Stacks
Explain the concept of Stacks
Demonstrate how Stacks follow LIFO (Last In First Out principles)
Use stack relations, push and pop from the stack
Use a buffer stack to reorder the items in a queue
Demonstrate and Explain how to merge two sorted stacks to be one sorted stack
Queues and Stacks
Combine Queues and Stacks to solve problems
Tree Stucture
Tree Structure Basics
Describe Tree structures
Explain Tree node names such as Root, Parent, Child, Leaf and Sibling
Explain Tree branches and their relationships
Use of a tree structure
Identify and discuss tree structures in everyday life, such as family tree, various hierarchies, etc.
Use tree structures to model some concepts in everyday life, e.g., family tree, various hierarchies, etc.
Tree Traverse
Explain breadth first search in Tree structures (Left subtree - then right)
Operate breadth first search in Tree structures (Left subtree - then right)
Explain depth first search in Tree structures (one level of children nodes then repeat)
Operate depth first search in Tree structures (one level of children nodes then repeat)
Differentiate breadth first search and depth first search in a tree
Heaps
Heap Basics
Explain how the heap is a special case of trees
Heap Operations
Execute heapify the heaps
Insert a new element to a heap
Extract the root from a heap
Apply heaps to real life applications
Identify parent nodes in a data heap
Identify child nodes in a data heap
Algorithms
Sequencial Execution
Sequence Basic Concepts
Explain simple sequences are an order of events
Arrange events in a desired order
Sequence Concepts
Discuss optimisation of order
Find the correct positions to add new events in execution order
Concurrent Execution
Concurrent sequences
Demonstrate how big tasks can be split into smaller interleaving  tasks
Schedule the subtasks from big tasks to optimise the use of resources and improve fairness
Parallel sequences
Explain that parallel two or more actions executing simultaneously
Demonstrate that parallel two or more actions executing simultaneously
Execute parallel execution in order to optimise tasks
Flowcharts
Flowchart Basics
Explain the basic elements of a Flowchart: Start, End & Actions
Explain additional elements in a Flowchart: Conditional, Input/Output, and Event
Create an algorithm using a Flowchart and blocks for start, end, conditional, input/output, event
Describe a Flowchart with connections and relations
Create a Flowchart with loops and changing of events
Apply flowcharts in real life problems
Illustrate the decomposition of problems into flowcharts
Sorting
Introduction to Sorting
Discuss how groups of items or data can be clustered into groups
Show how numbers can be sorted and scaled based on group average
Sort with a Buffer
Explain that one or more buffers may be needed to help with sorting
Explain and demostrate sorting using one buffer
Bubble Sort
Discuss how bubble sort exchanges adjacent pairs of data
Explain that in bubble sort bigger data moves to the end. It is similar to bigger bubbles emerging to the surface
Explain and demostrate sorting using bubble sort
Explain how the ‘Bubble Sort’ algorithm works
Be able to reproduce a Bubble sort of a given data structure
Heap Sort
Explain that heap sort can be used to sort a set of data
Demonstrate how Heap sort constructs and maintains a heap and the current min or max is removed from the heap in each round
Explain that Heap sort is more efficient than bubble sort
Merge Sort
Explain the concept of merging items
Be able to reproduce a Merge sort of a given data structure
Searching
Searching Introduction
Explain and demonstrate why searching is important and very useful in everyday life
Random Search
Explain and demonstrate that searching for items at random is unpredictable and inefficient
Explain how a random search works
Linear Search
Explain how linear search works
Explain that the linear search is better than random search but it is still inefficient
Explain how a linear search algorithm operates
Be able to reproduce a linear search of a given data structure
Binary Search
Explain how a Binary search involves sorting a list first
Demonstrate Binary search {halves the search space in each round}
Discuss why a Binary search is more efficient than linear search
Explain how a Binary search algorithm operates
Be able to reproduce a Binary search of a given data structure
Algorithm Concepts
Algorithms Basics
Explain that an algorithm is a set of instructions used to complete a task
Explain that an algorithm is the process of solving a problem - separate from any language, the process of a solution
Be able to reproduce a simple algorithm
Be able to map an algorithm out into a flowchart of events
Fundamentals of Algorithms
Representing Algorithms
Explain the purpose of an input.
Explain the purpose of an output.
Reproduce assigning an input and using it as an output
Explain the term algorithm.
Explain the term decomposition.
Use a systematic approach to problem solving and algorithm creation
Represent algorithms using pseudo-code.  Interpret pseudo-code algorithms.
Use trace tables to determine how algorithms work and what their purpose is.
Explain simple algorithms in terms of their inputs, processing and outputs.
Representing selection algorithms using pseudo-code.
Representing selection algorithms using flowcharts.
Explain the term Pseudocode
Explain and demonstrate a truth table
Searching Algorithms
Compare and contrast linear and binary search algorithms.
Sorting Algorithms
Illustrate in pseudocode how to create a bubble sort algorithm.
Explain how the ‘Merge Sort’ algorithm works.
Illustrate the steps to sort a set of data with merge sort.
Read/trace the merge sort algorithm.
Compare and contrast merge sort and bubble sort algorithms.
Programming Paradigms
OOP (object oriented programming)
OOP Basics
Ability to decompose a problem into objects and classes
Explain how an object is created
Explain why we use objects in programs
Explain that objects have both behaviours and attributes
Explain the term class and its relation to objects
Explain the comparison of a class as a blueprint to an object
Create a blank object constructor
Create attributes within an object (self)
Explain the term constructor
Explain that constructor is initialised upon creation of an object
Explain that a method is a function within a class
Be able to instantiate a class to create an object
Be able to define a method within a class
Be able to call methods within a class
Explain the relation between keyboard events and object calls
Encapsulation
Demonstrate Hiding data implementation by restricting access to public methods
Explain the concept of encapsulating an object to protect certain elements
Explain the difference between public and private methods
Create and call public methods
Create and call private methods
Abstraction
Creating concepts that are not associated with any particular instance
Explain the concept of Abstraction, only exposing elements that are needed
Be able to breakdown an elements into set of pieces that should be either public or private
Be able to create public variables
Be able to create private variables
Inheritance
Discuss the relationship between two objects, specifically inheritance
Explain the concept of inheritance as it relates to real world objects
Explain the concept of inheritance reusing common set of logic across multiple objects
Explain the relation between a parent class and a child class
Create a child class that inherits from a parent class
Create common methods that should be inherited in a given scenario
Polymorphism
Create a One name many forms, single interface to represent multiple different types
Explain the concept of polymorphism, a child retaining or overwriting their own methods when inheriting
Create a polymorphic class that inherits from a parent some elements
Explain that the same name can be used to overwrite common methods to make them unique to a child class
Functional Programming
Game Concepts
Use events to handle input from the user to control a scene
Explain the concept of updating or switching a frame to update a scene
Create and delete a basic set of shapes in a scene (rectangle, circle, triangle)
Explain the relation between coordinate systems and pixel mapping on a screen
Explain how music files are stored and loaded into a program
Load a music or audio file from a given path on a system
Explain image 'hitboxes' or 'surfaces' and how these define the area of an image or font
Load and use a surface to place an image or font in a scene
Explain how a scoreboard is functionally set up to quickly read and write from a file
Read and return a hierarchy from a file
Explain the concept of a sprite
Load a sprite into memory
Use the surface of a sprite to 'draw' or 'blit' it onto a screen
Explain the concept of 'clocks' and 'ticks' within game and their function of controlling the speed of a program
Explain the term 'FPS' or Frames Per Second
Demonstrate how to establish a clock to control the framerate of a scene
Explain what a frame rate (FPS) is and how it relates to movement on a screen
Explain what a comfortable/ideal framerate (FPS) is
Explain the differences between a low and high framerate (FPS)
Explain the comparison between framerate and a flipbook
Explain that an object on a screen has a bondary or bounding box of coordinates that defines its size
Demonstrate how to collect inputs from the keyboard an mouse
Explain that a mouse or cursors position on a screen is represented as a coordinate in pixels
Explain how a program must handle an event
Explain the concept of a game loop and how it controls the display
Be able to identify and conclude a game loop
Style
Explain how indentation is a way to show that a group of statements belong to a particular block of code
Demonstrate how to spot indentation errors in a block of code
Create basic code with correct indentation
Create complex nested code with correct indentation
Explain CamelCase as a format of writing code in a legible way, ArrayOfAnimals
Explain SnakeCase as a format of writing code in a legible way, array_of_animals
Create a descriptive comment for a block of code
Create a multi-line comment for a block of code
Explain that coding style can be unique to an programmer
Keywords
Explain the term keyword and how it defines the recognised words in a programming language
Explain the continue keyword and its use to skip an iteration or operation
Explain the finally keyword and its use to execute a section of code upon completion of the previous
Explain the return keyword and its use to bring back a result from a called action
Demonstrate how to spot and use keywords in a program
Discrete Mathematics
Counting by Listing
Counting using a tree structure
List all the possibilities using a tree structure
Count all the possibilities using the tree structure
Counting using a multi-edge graph
List all the possibilities using a multi-edge graph
Count all the possibilities using the multi-edge graph
Winning Strategies
Game concepts
Explain the games and strategies via a story
Use game strategies on a card game
Winning via working backwards
Explain why in some games, there is a way to work backwards to find the winning strategies
Balance Problems
Introduction to Balance Problem
Introduce the concept of balance via a story
Comparing the weights between two items on a balance
Balance substitute
Explain that two sides can be equalised if the balance is balanced.
Demonstrate how to find a solution when a problem is blanaced
Demonstrate how to find a solution when a problem is not blanaced
Software Engineering
Periodic phenomenon
Periodic activities
Discuss how  many everyday activities are periodic, e.g., pendulum motions, earth rotation, etc
Identify and explain the periodic phenomenon in daily life by giving examples
Link periodity with division
Explain that the period is the divisor and the remainder is crucial in solving the problems with periods
Use division and the remainder to solve problems with periods
Use periodity to solve problems
Analyse the periods in a problem and apply division to solve the problem
Aspects of software development
Aspects of software development
Describe how algorithms can be tested for the presence of errors, using normal (typical) data.
Describe how algorithms can be tested for the presence of errors, using boundary (extreme) data.
Describe how algorithms can be tested for the presence of errors, using erroneous data.
Descibe the various errors that may occur during the development of software.
Explain the purpose of software testing.
Ethical, legal and enviromental impacts of digital technology on wider society, including issues of privacy
Ethical, legal and enviromental impacts of digital technology on wider society, including issues of privacy
Discuss the impact of technology based around given issues.

children.name: AI CyberSecurity & Databases
AI (Artificial Intelligence)
AI Basics
Explain the term 'intelligent' as it relates to the real world
Describe who 'Alan Turing' is and his contributions to recognising computer as intelligent
Explain the term 'search' in relation to AI, solving a problem by finding the best possible solution
Explain the term 'logic' in relation to AI, solving problems by making informed guesses or inference
Explain the term 'uncertainty' in relation to AI, making guesses about the environment through probabilities
Explain the term 'learning' in relation to AI, improving a systems performance over time
Explain the outcome of a Zero-Sum game
Apply Artificial Intelligence concepts to flow chart out a problem for a machine to learn
Be able to categorise items as an AI would
Minimax
Explain the term Minimax, a search algorithm that finds the next optimal move
Explain that minimax operates on a graph structure following paths until the optimal move is found
Explain the concept of an AI agent and how it relates to a Minimax game
Explain a maximising and minimising player
Demonstrate the process to score a graph using the same process a Minimax algorithm will take
Be able to reproduce a basic Minimax game with a player and human operator
Machine Learning
Explain the term machine learning and how it relates to the real world
Explain unsupervised learning, an agent being left to figure out a task on its own
Explain supervised learning, an agent being assisted with prompts to figure out a task
Explain the process of training an agent
Explain the term classification, assigning classes (labels) to items
Neural Networks
Explain the supervised learning algorithm 'Neural Networks'
Explain how a neural network structure relates to the networks within our own brains
Explain how a weight affects the outcome of a neural network
Explain how weights in neural networks are processed by a function and an output is produced
Explain the input layers of a neural network and their function
Explain the hidden layers of a neural network and their function
Explain the output layers of a neural network and their function
Be able to create and train a basic neural network model
Explain the term epoch as used to describe training a neural network
Reinforcement Learning
Explain the concept of reinforced learning
Explain the concept of positive reinforcement and its real life examples
Explain the concept of negative reinforcement and its real life examples
Be able to break down and maximise the rewards for a given path with reinforced learning
Be able to reproduce a simple reinforced learning algorithm
Explain a constrained environment
Explain why a Q-Table is used to record information
Explain how a Q-table can be used to count the maximum rewards for a situation
Image Processing
Explain the idea of computer image processing
Explain how a computer sees images as a collection of pixels
Explain that a pixel is the smallest item of a digital image
Explain that a pixel is a collection of colour values
Be able to load an image into memory
Be able to convert an image into greyscale
Be able to flip an image across either axis
Be able to invert the colours displayed in an image
Be able to use a dataset of images to merge the common features across them
Object Detection
Explain the concept of computational object detection
Explain that the input of object detection can be an image or scenario with several objects
Explain the contract of a bounding box
Explain that the output of object detection can be bounding boxes with classification labels
Explain an agent can have a confidence in its detection outputs
Be able to reproduce a simple common object detection on an image
Emotion Recognition
Be able to reproduce a simple emotion detection on an image
Be able to reproduce a multiple confidence emotion detection on an image
Explain the concept of computational emotion detection
Explain the similarities and differences between object and emotion recognition
Databases
Data Analysis
Be able to assess data from a table
Be able to identify outliers in a set of data
Relational databases and structured query language (SQL)
Relational databases
Explain the concept of a database.

children.name: Explain the concept of a relational database.
children.computational_concepts: Relational databases and structured query language (SQL)

children.name: Explain that the use of a relational database facilitates the elimination of data inconsistency and data redundancy.

children.name: Describe database concept of tables
children.computational_concepts: Relational databases and structured query language (SQL)

children.name: Describe database concept of records
children.computational_concepts: Relational databases and structured query language (SQL)

children.name: Describe database concept of fields
children.computational_concepts: Relational databases and structured query language (SQL)

children.name: Describe database concept of primary keys
children.computational_concepts: Relational databases and structured query language (SQL)

children.name: Describe database concept of foreign keys

children.name: Structured query language (SQL)
Use SQL to retrieve data from a relational database, using the commands: SELECT FROM WHERE ORDER BY…ASC | DESC

children.name: Use SQL to insert data into a relational database using the commands. INSERT INTO table_name (column1, column 2 …) VALUES (value1, value2 …)

children.name: Use SQL to edit and delete data in a database using the commands. UPDATE table_name SET column1 = value1, column2 = value2 ... WHERE condition DELETE FROM table_name WHERE condition

children.name: Fundamentals of cyber security
Fundamentals of cyber security
Be able to define the term cyber security
Describe the main purposes of cyber security
Cyber security threats
Explain the cyber security threat of social engineering techniques
Explain the cyber security threat of malicious code
Explain the cyber security threat of weak and default passwords
Explain the cyber security threat of misconfigured access rights
Explain the cyber security threat of removable media
Explain the  cyber security threat of unpatched and/or outdated software.
Explain what penetration testing is and what it is used for.
Social engineering
Define the term social engineering
Describe what social engineering is and how it can be protected against.
Explain social engineering concept; blagging (pretexting)
Explain social engineering concept: phishing
Explain social engineering concept: pharming
Explain social engineering concept: shouldering (or shoulder surfing).
Malicious code
Define the term 'malware'
Describe what malware is and how it can be protected against.
Describe a computer virus a form of malware
Describe trojan a form of malware
Describe spyware a form of malware
Describe adware a form of malware
Methods to detect and prevent cyber security threats
Explain biometric security measures (particularly for mobile devices)
children.cs_category_3_lesson: Methods to detect and prevent cyber security threats

children.name: Explain password systems security measures
children.cs_category_3_lesson: Methods to detect and prevent cyber security threats

children.name: Explain CAPTCHA (or similar) security measures
children.cs_category_3_lesson: Methods to detect and prevent cyber security threats

children.name: Explain using email confirmations to confirm a user’s identity as a security measure
children.cs_category_3_lesson: Methods to detect and prevent cyber security threats

children.name: Explain automatic software updates as a form of security measure
children.cs_category_3_lesson: Methods to detect and prevent cyber security threats
